Message.Title: T welcome to the 40 dollar club
Message.Msg: we are going to see 40 this week!! welcome AT&T. Only a real fool wanting to lose money would short or sell T this week.
And this post coming from a Nazi.

Message.Title: Big buy back
Message.Msg: AT&T Inc. (T) boosted its buyback program by 300 million shares, as the telecommunications heavyweight seeks to bolster shareholder value.
Old news Wilkes, where you been all weekend?! :-)

Message.Title: Avoid AT&T's 4.7% Dividend
Message.Msg: AT&T has rewarded shareholders with an impressive performance through present date. AT&T is a proxy for the bond market. A 10 Year Treasury Bond yields 1.58%. AT&T's 4.7% dividend yield beats the 10 Year Bond by 312 basis points. If revenue growth is the engine for future profits, then AT&T's earnings growth appears to be backed by share buybacks versus organic revenue growth. In the 2nd quarter, AT&T bought back $2.5 billion in stock buybacks. These reduced 75.8 million AT&T shares from the total outstanding shares. A company without revenue growth will eventually decline. Margin expansion, earnings per share, and shareholders will be rewarded if revenue growth creates an increase in earnings per share. Reviewing the SEC 10Q filings, the revenues and earnings growth do not support purchasing AT&T shares for a 4.7% dividend yield. Revenue growth is the bread and butter to future earnings per share growth. AT&T legacy business lines and current business model are generating a flat revenue growth trajectory. http://seekingalpha.com/article/760771-avoid-at-t-s-4-7-dividend?source=yahoo

At church of course. With a book value of $17.79 per share a buy back at this price range will dilute the book value. Of course only we old fogies care about book value so it should only help the stock price. You kids will never learn.
A buyback at any price will dilute the book value since the shareholder equity will drop. Just the nature of the beast.

Interesting article but I think one point was missed. That is the 4.7% dividend is very likely to get back to the 6% when T increases their dividend. The dividend could be raised to sixty cents without hurting cash flow because AT&T earnings are 66 cents and increasing. At $40 a share, a 60 cent dividend would be a 6% return. Right now AT&T is using their cash to buy back shares. When thy change that policy, they can easily increase the dividend because there will be fewer shares.
In the case of AT&T that is true. However, if AT&T shares were to drop below book value a repurchase plan would increase book value per share.
Buybacks make the most sense when purchased at or below intrinsic value.."Warren Buffet"
If the shares were to drop below book value the company better come in and buy the remaining 450 million shares of the buyback authorization in a single afternoon!

"At church of course. With a book value of $17.79 per share a buy back at this price range will dilute the book value. Of course only we old fogies care about book value so it should only help the stock price. You kids will never learn." Given the historic slide in rates every going concern in the world is trying to refi and lower future period interest rate expense. Take a firm like IBM that just borrowed 10 year money at 1.875% to set a new modern corporate benchmark. It pays $3.40 per year which is close to 1.8%. The key metric for buyback justification is Operating Cash Flow per share -- for a going concern that's the current yield on buyback market price to consider -- in the case of T it is highly probable that total Operating Cash Flow will grow. And you can't forget the divi yield at around 4.7% in T's case. Besides doing refi's as debt comes due, going concerns with financial strength are going to take advantage of this interest rate environment or fall behind other strong equities. My only concern is buying back the wire line value of T stock. But the strategy seems to be to keep wire line. You have to play the hand the market deals.
Did you have your Bible with you when you posted this....I/D/I/O/T/

It will also help them "boost" the dividend while keeping the total payout flat and thus not affecting the payout ratio. If you payout the same total but to a small share count, their payout per share will increase, but they won't have to return more total cash to shareholders. Makes the shares more attractive without any increased charges to the balance sheet/cash flow.

Message.Title: technical analysis basics
Message.Msg: I've been watching the market closely now that I'm retired and I now understand how difficult it is to predict, even at the broad ETF level, especially at this particular point in time. The analysis they provide has been extremely helpful and maybe it can help you. http://STOCK-SELL-CHARTS.INFO

Message.Title: Year End Price
Message.Msg: Any ideas????
One evaluation is use the forward P/E estimate and projected earnings to derive a price. Then the potential price is calculatable.

I've used that method in the past and haven't had good results. Never know with this economy but bought into T June 2010 at price of $24.30 only for divy. Very happy with 2 yr price increase but not worry about any decrease in divy. Thinking about investing another 20K only for divy since banks don't offer decent rates.
